THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 15, 1922.
SHOEMAKER ADDRESSES
ASSEMBLY
Continued from page 1

BLACK AND BLUE OVERWHELM DREXEL

Stevens, President of the Y. M.
C. A., announced that Rev. Shoemaker, Rev. Bookman, of New
York, and Mr. Hamilton, a graduate of Oxford, would discuss the
subject of religion immediately after the assembly in Room 110, Mechanical Engineering Building. All
students were invited to attend.
Sherwood announced that a
Freshman "Pep" Committee, to
take over the work that the Sophomore "Pep" Committee and the
Student Council have been doing,
would be formed. The Student
Council has decided to close the
Gilman Hall Memorial Room to all
undergraduates except Seniors.
Sherwood called for an active, energetic school spirit, both on and
off the campus. He directed the
students' attention to Hopkins'
greatest tradition, the Honor System, and recommended that it be
supported in all things, both great
and small. The Cotillon Club is
giving the receipts from its dances
after games to the Cross Country
team. There is a prospect of the
team's disbanding if financial sup
port is not secured. For this reason, the dances should be especially
well attended by the students.
Vanneman called for volunteers
for various stunts that are to be
performed in the St. John's game
parade. He.asked that plenty of
wood be brought for the bonfire
next Friday night, the eve of the
Maryland State game. The Freshmen are required to bring at least
two boxes or their equivalent before five o'clock Friday afternoon.
The Freshmen were urged to assemble in the upper quadrangle
promptly at half past one before
the games. Yell practice will bo
held at the barn daily this week for
all classes, and the Freshman yell
practice on Tuesday afternoon
will be suspended.
Hay—"He is sure a farsighted
man."
Dees—"How so?"
Hay—"He had a fire extinguisher put in his coffin."—The
Bee.

Continued from page 1

Skinner scored the first touchdown in the second half when he
dashed around left end for 30
yards after a short kick by Drexel. Coady again kicked goal. The
last part of the game was a repetition of the first half except that
it was the subs instead of the regulars doing the work of piling up
points. Skinner, Middleton and
Balsam continued to carry the ball
for big gains and crossed the line
three more times before the final
whistle sounded.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 15, 1922.
SHOEMAKER ADDRESSES
ASSEMBLY
Continued from page 1

BLACK AND BLUE OVERWHELM DREXEL

Stevens, President of the Y. M.
C. A., announced that Rev. Shoemaker, Rev. Bookman, of New
York, and Mr. Hamilton, a graduate of Oxford, would discuss the
subject of religion immediately after the assembly in Room 110, Mechanical Engineering Building. All
students were invited to attend.
Sherwood announced that a
Freshman "Pep" Committee, to
take over the work that the Sophomore "Pep" Committee and the
Student Council have been doing,
would be formed. The Student
Council has decided to close the
Gilman Hall Memorial Room to all
undergraduates except Seniors.
Sherwood called for an active, energetic school spirit, both on and
off the campus. He directed the
students' attention to Hopkins'
greatest tradition, the Honor System, and recommended that it be
supported in all things, both great
and small. The Cotillon Club is
giving the receipts from its dances
after games to the Cross Country
team. There is a prospect of the
team's disbanding if financial sup
port is not secured. For this reason, the dances should be especially
well attended by the students.
Vanneman called for volunteers
for various stunts that are to be
performed in the St. John's game
parade. He.asked that plenty of
wood be brought for the bonfire
next Friday night, the eve of the
Maryland State game. The Freshmen are required to bring at least
two boxes or their equivalent before five o'clock Friday afternoon.
The Freshmen were urged to assemble in the upper quadrangle
promptly at half past one before
the games. Yell practice will bo
held at the barn daily this week for
all classes, and the Freshman yell
practice on Tuesday afternoon
will be suspended.
Hay—"He is sure a farsighted
man."
Dees—"How so?"
Hay—"He had a fire extinguisher put in his coffin."—The
Bee.

Skinner scored the first touchdown in the second half when he
dashed around left end for 30
yards after a short kick by Drexel. Coady again kicked goal. The
last part of the game was a repetition of the first half except that
it was the subs instead of the regulars doing the work of piling up
points. Skinner, Middleton and
Balsam continued to carry the ball
for big gains and crossed the line
three more times before the final
whistle sounded.
